Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Mechanism for Cation Exchange and Doping in Semiconducting Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Phillip Geissler from the University of California Berkeley is supported in an International Collaboration in Chemistry award by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program and the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program; his collaborator, Eran Rabani at Tel Aviv University, is simultaneously supported by the U.S.-Israel Binational Science Foundation. The project is motivated by the fact that the past 20 years have seen a revolution in chemists' ability to make materials on extremely small scales, notably in the form of "nanocrystals" (nanometer-sized excerpts of crystalline materials). Realizing the immense technological promise of nanocrystals, however, requires much more control over their composition, shape, structure, and relative arrangements than is currently possible. This project concerns a recently discovered route towards gaining control of this kind: exchanging one set of ions in a nanocrystal with a chemically distinct set of ions, remarkably without altering the nanocrystal's structure. The mechanism, energetics, dynamics, and physical consequences of such "cation exchange" are very poorly understood, greatly limiting its precise application. The project uses tools of theory and computation to develop and explore models that shed light on the chemical underpinnings of ion exchange. It further evaluates the consequences of exchange on electronic properties relevant to desirable technological advances.

Specific activities of this project include (i) construction of models for exploring reaction mechanisms of doping and ion exchange, (ii) development and application of state-of-the-art computational techniques needed to explore the long-time behaviors of these models, and (iii) the assessment of resulting electronic properties. Interaction models are built through judicious comparison with electronic structure calculations and experimental measurements. Molecular dynamics simulations combined with techniques such as transition path sampling are employed to examine how impurities/cations enter the nanocrystal from solution, how they diffuse through the host lattice, and how they exchange places with host atoms. In order to calculate emergent electronic properties, semiempirical pseudopotential models adequate for doped materials and heterostructures are developed. Finally, a theory for heavily doped nanocrystals in the spirit of a "hydrogenic-like" model for multiple impurities is being constructed to elucidate at a fundamental level the alignment of bands, localization of excitons, electron-hole interactions, and how these properties depend on the size, shape, and choice of materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemists can synthesize and manipulate nanoscale materials a billionth of a meter in size with an increasing degree of control and precision. The ability to tailor the properties of nanoparticles and to guide their assembly into functional materials has implications for technology ranging from solar energy harvesting to drug delivery. Fulfilling the promise of nanoscience, however, requires a more detailed, fundamental understanding of the processes which underpin the creation and transformation of nanomaterials. With the support of NSF grant 1416161, we have made substantial contributions to this understanding.

Our work has centered around understanding the microscopic details of chemical transformations of nanoparticles. A common way to modify the properties of nanoparticles is to “dope” them with ions whose identity differs from those of the native crystal. The introduction of a large number of such dopant ions results in the replacement of native ions for dopants, a process known as ion exchange. While such reactions are a promising way of designing novel nanoparticles, their details are not yet understood. Using theoretical and computational tools, we have gained significant insight into the workings of such reactions. We constructed a model which captures one of the important features of ion exchange reactions – the difference in size between native and dopant ions. Attempting to fit atoms with different sizes into an ordered, regular crystal lattice creates elastic strain. In order to mitigate this strain, the atoms arrange themselves into alternating patterns. We thoroughly characterized these patterns using computer simulations and developed new theoretical tools to analyze coexistence between different kinds of patterns. Such patterns have a significant impact on the mechanism of simulated ion exchange reactions, as we uncovered with computer simulations. These findings have allowed us to rationalize the observation of alternating patterns observed experimentally in ion-exchanged nanoparticles, and they further suggest ways in which such patterns could be manipulated. Our work has resulting in publications in the journals Physical Review Letters and Physical Review B, and further manuscripts are in preparation.

In addition to internal reorganization, an important question for ion exchange is how dopant ions enter the particle in the first place. This process is complicated by the presence of hair-like “ligands” which decorate nanoparticle surfaces. These molecules help stabilize nanoparticles in solutions. Moreover, they can interact among themselves to form different “phases.” At high temperatures, the ligands’ orientations are essentially random, while at low temperatures they line up like rows of corn. Using computer simulation, we have thoroughly characterized the properties of each phase and the transition between them. With the properties that we measured, we have constructed a simplified theoretical model for the ligands which will allow us to answer questions about how the ligands’ phases impact nanoparticles’ assembly into functional materials. In addition, the insight we have gleaned into the microscopic motion of ligand molecules will serve as the basis for future studies of how ions successfully navigate through the “field” of ligands to reach the nanoparticle surface.

Finally, in the course of our research we collaborated with experimental chemists to understand the morphology of gold nanoparticles. In the course of being chemically “etched” – essentially dissolving – nanoparticles take on different shapes, depending on the structure of their crystal lattice and the concentration of etchant molecules. We created a model for nanoparticle etching which centers around the key fact that atoms which are surrounded by few neighboring atoms dissolve more quickly than those with many neighbors. Computer simulations of this model agreed closely with experiments and allowed us to unveil the microscopic reasons behind nanoparticle shape changes. With an understanding of how to achieve novel shapes, scientists will be able to better design nanoparticles customized for catalysis and for assembly into novel functional materials. This work was published in the journals Science and Nano Letters.
